title: Git Workflow Strategies
question: Describe some common Git workflows used in team environments. What are the pros and cons of each?
answer: Common workflows: 1) Feature Branch - each feature in its own branch, merged via PR. Simple and widely used. 2) GitFlow - uses develop, feature, release, and hotfix branches. More structured but complex. 3) Trunk-Based - short-lived branches merged frequently to main. Requires good CI/CD and testing. 4) Forking - contributors fork the repo, used in open source. Choose based on team size, release cadence, and CI/CD maturity.
explanation: There's no universally 'best' workflow - it depends on your team's needs. Trunk-based development is trending in DevOps-mature organizations because it encourages frequent integration and reduces merge conflicts. Feature branching is great for teams needing code review gates. GitFlow suits projects with scheduled releases.

codeExamples.label: Feature branch workflow
codeExamples.code:
# Start new feature
git checkout main
git pull origin main
git checkout -b feature/add-login

# Work on feature, commit changes
git add .
git commit -m "Add login form"

# Push and create PR
git push origin feature/add-login
# Create PR on GitHub/GitLab

# After PR approved and merged
git checkout main
git pull origin main
git branch -d feature/add-login

codeExamples.label: Trunk-based development
codeExamples.code:
# Short-lived branch (1-2 days max)
git checkout main
git pull
git checkout -b small-change

# Make small, focused changes
git add .
git commit -m "Refactor auth module"

# Merge quickly (after CI passes)
git checkout main
git pull
git merge small-change
git push
git branch -d small-change

commonMistakes: Keeping feature branches open too long, leading to painful merges
Not pulling from main regularly to stay up-to-date
Using complex workflows (like GitFlow) for small teams or simple projects
